Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adjoint tomography of fault zone environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
We are investigating the subsurface structure of fault zones using a variety of seismic phases: surface waves, body waves, fault zone head waves, and fault zone trapped waves. By using a larger portion of the recorded seismic wavefield, we should be able to better resolve the fault zone structures to which the waves are sensitive. We use an adjoint-based tomographic inversion technique that relies on highly accurate, three-dimensional seismic wavefield simulations. The study has the following three components: (1) simulations of synthetic seismograms in realistic, complex 3D fault zone models, including clarifying the allowable ranges of geometrical and material variations that produce the observed characteristics of recorded head and trapped waves; (2) analysis of volumetric sensitivities of various fault zone, body, and surface phases to key fault zone structures at depth; (3) iterative adjoint tomographic inversions for the structures of the San Andreas fault near Parkfield and different sections of the San Jacinto fault zone.

Large damaging earthquakes originate on faults kilometers below Earth's surface. A detailed characterization of the physical setting where earthquakes nucleate and rupture has not yet been achieved. By modeling seismic waves that are particularly sensitive to the structures of fault zones, we can image the subsurface structure of fault zones. The basic difficulty in imaging fault zones stems from their multi-scale and strong variations in structure, which are evident at the surface and within boreholes. By using accurate seismic wave propagation models, the study will provide the most detailed description of fault zone structure afforded by the recorded data. The project focuses on two societally relevant fault zones in southern California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquakes originate on fault zones that are far underground, under conditions that are largely unknown. We can only characterize these fault zones by using remote techniques such as seismic imaging. Seismic imaging of fault zones seeks to quantify the properties of fault zones by measuring the variations in shapes and travel times of seismic waves. The accuracy of seismic images of fault zones depends on how accurately seismic waves are modeled. This project calculated fault zone sensitivities for a wide range of seismic waves that sample simplified, yet realistic, models of fault zones, including a slow fault zone core sandwiched between two different materials on two sides of the fault. We also examined several different three-dimensional tomographic models containing fault zones in southern California, and we performed earthquake simulations to compare how well the synthetic waveforms from these models agreed with recorded waveforms. We deployed 193 seismic sensors along the Denali fault in central Alaska in a section that produced a magnitude 7.9 earthquake in 2002. Our goal was to investigate the influence of fault zone structures on the waves generated from regional earthquakes. Preliminary results suggest that such an array will be able to provide basic characteristics of the Denali fault zone. We applied three independent data sets (tomographic arrival times, receiver functions, fault zone head waves) to document the existence of a major crustal boundary along the Denali fault, revealing a 10 km step in crustal thickness from south of the Denali fault to north of the Denali fault. Our new data sets from Alaska and the methodological advances for fault zone imaging provide improvements in the quest to document the structural variations in the regions where earthquakes originate.
